ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Bilateral Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence (SSCD)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Confirmed by CT; supported by Tullio phenomenon, autophony, low-frequency air-bone gaps with present acoustic reflexes, and enlarged SP/AP ratios on ECoG.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Ménière's Disease
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Previously diagnosed due to fullness/imbalance and enlarged ECoG, but ruled out by non-fluctuating symptoms, presence of third-window signs, and CT findings.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Ossicular Fixation
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Considered due to air-bone gaps, but ruled out by presence of acoustic reflexes and hypersensitive bone conduction.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess degree and type of hearing loss given complaints of pressure and hearing difficulty.
To evaluate speech understanding and validate pure-tone thresholds.
To assess middle ear function and rule out common conductive pathologies.
To differentiate between ossicular fixation (absent reflexes) and third-window lesions (present reflexes).
To assess for endolymphatic hydrops or third-window indicators (enlarged SP/AP ratio).
To evaluate vestibular function given complaints of constant imbalance and Tullio phenomenon.
To visualize temporal bone anatomy and confirm dehiscence of the superior semicircular canal.
To verify hearing aid fitting to prescriptive targets.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Comprehensive evaluation revealed bilateral mixed hearing loss with significant low-frequency air-bone gaps. Paradoxically, acoustic reflexes were preserved and tympanometry was normal, strongly suggesting a third-window lesion rather than middle ear pathology. ECoG showed enlarged SP/AP ratios bilaterally, and CT imaging confirmed bilateral Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right mild-to-moderate mixed loss; Left slight-to-mild mixed sloping to moderate-severe loss. Significant low-frequency air-bone gaps (15-20 dB Right, 30 dB Left at 250 Hz).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRTs 35 dB HL (Right) and 30 dB HL (Left); WRS excellent (96% Right, 100% Left).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Ipsilateral reflexes present and normal bilaterally; contralateral reflexes mostly normal.

tests.name: Electrocochleography (ECoG)
tests.result_summary: Enlarged SP/AP amplitude ratios bilaterally (Right 0.76, Left 0.71).

tests.name: Vestibular Evaluation
tests.result_summary: Normal VOG, calorics, and rotary chair. CDP showed decreased vestibular utilization (falls on SOT 5 & 6).

tests.name: Spiral CT Scan
tests.result_summary: Confirmed dehiscence of the superior semicircular canal bilaterally.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Patient returned for hearing aid fitting on the left ear. Verification was performed to ensure audibility without exceeding loudness tolerance, given the patient's sensitivity to loud sounds.

tests.name: Real Ear Measures (REM)
tests.result_summary: Verified 15-channel digital BTE to NAL-NL1 targets at 50, 65, and 80 dB SPL inputs.

proposed_items: Middle fossa approach for superior canal plugging (offered)
counseling_actions: Explained that symptoms are caused by SSCD (bone thinning) rather than Ménière's disease
Clarified that the 'hearing gap' is due to hypersensitive bone conduction, not middle ear dysfunction
Discussed surgical versus non-surgical management options
Counseled on hearing aid use, specifically regarding volume and potential eye movement triggers with loud sounds
Recommended annual monitoring of hearing and balance

escalation.rationale_short: For annual follow-up and monitoring of bilateral SSCD status.

expected_outcome: Patient elected not to undergo medical or surgical treatment.
Patient purchased a hearing aid for the left ear but returned it approximately 2 weeks later.
Patient did not wear the hearing aid.
